questions.text: Which of the following types of papillae on the tongue does not contain taste buds?
questions.solution:
• Filiform papillae are the only type of tongue papillae that lack taste buds
  • Responsible for creating the rough texture on the tongue surface, which aids in food manipulation and the perception of food texture, not taste

Fungiform papillae (Option A): are mushroom-shaped bumps on the tongue that contain taste buds and are sensitive to sweet, salty, sour, and umami flavors

Circumvallate papillae (Option C): are large, dome-shaped structures located at the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement:

Foliate papillae (Option D): are ridged structures on the sides of the tongue that contain taste buds and are particularly sensitive to sour flavors:

Types of Papilla in Tongue:

choices.text: Meissner's corpuscle - Sustained pressure and stretching

questions.text: Select the correct option regarding the function of receptors?
questions.solution: Pacinian corpuscles are specialized receptors that detect vibration and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting and are found deep in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential?
questions.solution:
• Potassium ions are the primary contributors to the resting membrane potential. The RMP is mainly determined by the K+ gradient across the cell membrane, as potassium ions move out of the cell through potassium leak channels.
  • The loss of positively charged K+ ions from the cell creates a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside, establishing the RMP, which is typically around -70 mV in neurons.

Resting membrane potential (RMP):

  • It is defined as the voltage difference between the exterior and interior of an excitable cell
  • In any cell, K+ is the major determinant of RMP
  • The major contribution of RMP is through passive diffusion of K+ ions followed by active diffusion through Na+-K+ ions

Generation of RMP:

questions.text:
The correct sequence of events in neuromuscular action potential conduction is:
1. Sodium channels open in the end plate.
2. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate.
3. Release of acetylcholine.
questions.solution:
Events in Neuromuscular Action Potential Conduction:

  1. Calcium enters at the nerve end plate: Calcium ions enter the nerve terminal when an action potential reaches the nerve end. This influx of calcium is crucial for the subsequent release of neurotransmitters.
  2. Release of acetylcholine: The entry of calcium ions into the nerve terminal triggers the release of acetylcholine (ACh) from vesicles into the synaptic cleft.
  3. Sodium channels open in the end plate: The binding of acetylcholine to receptors on the muscle end plate causes sodium channels to open, leading to an influx of sodium ions into the muscle cell and generating an action potential in the muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicle?
questions.solution:
The Na/l symporter (NIS) is responsible for the active transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells. It uses the sodium gradient to co-transport iodine into the cell from the bloodstream.



Pendrin (Option B):

  • Pendrin is an iodide/chloride exchanger located on the apical membrane of thyroid follicular cells.
  • It is involved in the movement of iodide into the follicle lumen but not in the transport of iodine into the thyroid follicular cells.

CI/I symporter (Option C): This option is incorrect as there is no known CI/I symporter in the thyroid.

questions.text: A man presents with an irregularly irregular pulse and dyspnoea. What is the expected finding in the jugular venous pressure (JVP)?
questions.solution:
In the JVP waveform, the 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. An absent 'a' wave is typically seen in atrial fibrillation, where the atria do not contract effectively due to irregular impulses.

Cannon a wave (Option B):

  • Are large, prominent waves in the JVP that occur when atrial contraction is against a closed tricuspid valve, often due to arrhythmias like complete heart block.

Prominent X descent (Option C):

  • The X descent in the JVP represents atrial relaxation and descent of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole.
  • Prominent X descent is generally seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation or right ventricular failure.

 Prominent Y descent (Option D):

  • The Y descent reflects the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.
  • Prominent Y descent can be seen in conditions such as constrictive pericarditis or right heart failure.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in the improvement of insulin resistance in Type 2 Diabetes mellitus with regular exercise and physical activities?
questions.solution:
This glucose transporter is found predominantly in muscle and adipose tissue. GLUT 4 is regulated by insulin and is crucial for the insulin-mediated uptake of glucose into these tissues. Regular exercise increases the number of GLUT 4 receptors on the cell membrane, improving glucose uptake and insulin sensitivity in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes mellitus.

GLUT 1 (Option A): This glucose transporter is found the brain and erythrocytes. It helps in the uptake of glucose across cell membranes but is not primarily responsible for the insulin-mediated glucose uptake in muscle cells.

GLUT 2 (Option B):This glucose transporter is located primarily in the liver, pancreas, and kidneys. It plays a role in glucose sensing and regulation of blood glucose levels but does not directly mediate the improvement of insulin resistance through physical activity.

GLUT 3 (Option C): This glucose transporter is found mainly in neurons and some other tissues. It is responsible for the uptake of glucose into the brain but does not significantly impact insulin resistance in skeletal muscles.

Learning objective:

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK22210/

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1 hour before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: Caffeine impairs with sleep by which of the following:
questions.solution:
• Caffeine works by blocking adenosine receptors.
  • Adenosine is a neurotransmitter that promotes sleep by slowing down nerve activity. By blocking adenosine, caffeine prevents the brain from sensing sleepiness, thereby promoting wakefulness.

Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness (Option B):

  • The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in arousal and wakefulness.
  • While it does play a role in promoting wakefulness, caffeine's primary mechanism of action is not through direct activation of the locus coeruleus.

No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1 hour before sleep (Option C):

Caffeine is well-known for its role in maintaining wakefulness by counteracting sleep-promoting mechanisms in the brain.

Activates histamine release and prevents sleep (Option D):

  • Histamine is involved in promoting wakefulness, but caffeine does not directly cause histamine release.
  • Its effect on sleep is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade rather than histamine pathways.

Learning objective:

Metabolic Theory

There are 2 centres located in the hypothalamus, which are in constant mutual inhibition.

  • Wake-Promoting Area: Located in the posterior hypothalamus- Tuberomammillary nucleus (TMN), releasing histamine.
    • The wake-promoting area stimulates two important nuclei of the reticular activating system, i.e., Raphe nuclei (RN), which produce serotonin, and Locus coeruleus (LC), which produce non-epinephrine.
    • These act at the level of the thalamus from which all the diffuse projections will reach the cortex and the active cortex means the person will remain awake.
    • This active cortex indefinitely produces metabolites with awakeness, primarily Adenosine.
    • An increase in adenosine acts at the level of the basal forebrain and stimulates the sleep-promoting area.
  • Sleep-Promoting Area: Located in the anterior hypothalamus- Ventrolateral preoptic nucleus (VLPO), releasing GABA.

References: UCSD

choices.text: A-Glucose, B-PAH, C- Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A-Glucose, B- Bicarbonate, C- Inulin and D - PAH
A-PAH, B-Inulin, C- Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A-Inulin, B- Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph below.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows renal clearance of different substances.

Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

  • Us: Urine concentration of the substance
  • V: Urine flow rate
  • Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Learning objective

Renal Clearance

CPAH>>CCr>>CInsulin [125ml/min (GFR)]>>Curea>>CNa+>>CGlucose/AA

choices.text: The threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to the opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is a refractory period

questions.text: Which statement is accurate about the nerve action potential curve provided?
questions.solution:
The given graph represents an action potential curve of a nerve.

Point B to D represents the refractory period, a phase during which a second action potential is impossible or difficult to trigger. This period includes the absolute refractory period (impossible to trigger a second action potential) and the relative refractory period (a second action potential can be triggered but requires a stronger stimulus).

Propagation of Action Potential:

  • Mechanism: Action potentials travel along the nerve fiber without diminishing. Depolarization at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions.
  • All-or-Nothing Principle: An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength.

Refractory Periods: (Option D)

  • Absolute Refractory Period: Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing another action potential.
  • Relative Refractory Period: Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarization.

Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibers, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy.

Energy Dependence: Na⁺-K⁺ Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP.

Factors Influencing Excitability:

  • Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺): Low extracellular Ca²⁺ increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na⁺ channels; high Ca²⁺ decreases excitability.
  • Local Anesthetics: Block voltage-gated Na+ channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane given below.
questions.solution:
The image represents facilitated diffusion, a passive transport that moves substances down their concentration gradient without using cellular energy but requires the assistance of specific carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane.

This process is essential for transporting large or polar molecules that cannot cross the cell membrane's lipid bilayer by simple diffusion.

Types of diffusion:


Primary active transport (Option C): This active transport uses cellular energy (ATP) to transport substances against their concentration gradient. This process often involves specific carrier proteins, such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.

Secondary active transport (Option D): This type of active transport uses the energy stored in the form of ion concentration gradients, established by primary active transport, to drive the transport of other substances against their concentration gradient.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?
questions.solution:
In preterm infants with RDS, surfactant deficiency leads to increased alveolar surface tension and reduced lung compliance.

This statement is accurate regarding surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance and are not opposing forces to each other.

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibers within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibers are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibers stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimize the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse

Reference: Pulmonary Compliance - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: What findings would be observed in a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury due to a road traffic accident, whereby the fracture fragment has penetrated the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract?
questions.solution:
The lateral dorsal column (fasciculus cuneatus) carries proprioceptive input from the ipsilateral upper limb, so injury here causes loss of arm proprioception on the same side.

The dorsal column tract of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration sensation, and fine touch.


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

A) Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception - Lower limb proprioception travels via the medial dorsal column (fasciculus gracilis), not the lateral part.

B) Absence of fine motor movement of fingers - Fine motor control is a motor function, not mediated by the sensory dorsal column tract.

D) Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception - Dorsal column fibers do not decussate until the medulla, so proprioception loss is always ipsilateral below the lesion.

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+and opening of slow K+ channels

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the segment marked in red on the myocardial action potential curve?
questions.solution: The paint marked on the myocardial action potential curve represents phase 2, the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential.

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?
questions.solution:
• The person experiences muscle weakness (paresis) without numbness, suggesting motor function impairment with preserved sensory function.
  • Pressure on larger, myelinated motor neurons (A fibers) during sleep likely causes temporary weakness, as A fibers are more pressure-sensitive than smaller, unmyelinated sensory neurons (C fibers).

A, B, and C Nerve Fibers

Nerve fibers are categorized by their diameter, conduction velocity, and myelination. A, B, and C fibers have distinct structures and functions.

Key Characteristics:

  • A Fibers: Large, myelinated, fast conduction; transmit sharp pain, proprioception, touch, and pressure.
  • B Fibers: Smaller, myelinated, slower conduction; regulate autonomic functions (e.g., heart rate, digestion).
  • C Fibers: Smallest, unmyelinated, slowest conduction; transmit dull pain, temperature, itch, and respond to multiple stimuli.

Subtypes of A Fibers

  • Aα: Motor function and proprioception.
  • Aβ: Sensory transmission for touch and pressure.
  • Aδ: Sharp pain and temperature sensations.

Sensitivity to Stimuli

  • A Fibers: Rapidly respond to light touch, pressure, and sharp pain due to myelination.
  • B Fibers: Involved in autonomic pathways; less sensitive to external stimuli.
  • C Fibers: React to noxious stimuli, inflammation, and physiological changes (e.g., hypoxia).

Learning Objective:


Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6121522/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551652/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539845/

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
The baroreceptor reflex is a mechanism that helps maintain blood pressure homeostasis by regulating heart rate, vascular tone, and cardiac output. It relies on negative feedback to counteract deviations from normal blood pressure levels.


Negative feedback mechanism: The body responds to a change by initiating actions that counteract the change, aiming to restore equilibrium.

Examples of negative feedback mechanisms:


Feedforward (Option A): Incorrect. Feedforward mechanisms predict changes and act in advance to maintain stability, such as anticipatory responses. The baroreceptor reflex, however, responds to changes already occurring in blood pressure.

Positive feedback (Option B): Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes, potentially leading to instability. For example, in pathologic conditions like hemorrhagic shock, positive feedback mechanisms may contribute to worsening hypotension, but this is not part of the normal baroreceptor reflex.

Both A & B are correct (Option D): Incorrect. Neither feedforward nor positive feedback applies to the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell- to-cell signaling is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Cell-to-Cell Signaling

Cell-to-cell signaling ensures coordination among cells for proper function and adaptation to environmental changes. This process involves various mechanisms, molecules, and receptors.

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment Ib is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram?
questions.solution:
Segment Ib is due to Laplace law where volume is increased but there is no rise in pressure,

Cystometrogram Phases and Laplace's Law

Phases of Cystometrogram

  • Initial (Filling) Phase:
    • The bladder fills with sterile fluid.
    • Intra-vesical pressure (Pves) rises.
    • Detrusor muscle contracts, causing initial pressure increase without volume change.
    • Divided into three segments:
      • Phase I: Up to 1/3 of max capacity.
      • Phase II: 1/3 to 2/3 of max capacity.
      • Phase III: 2/3 to max capacity.
    • Provides insights into detrusor properties, especially in neurogenic bladders.
  • Emptying Phase:
    • Characterized by rhythmic external urethral sphincter contractions and increased Pves.
    • High-frequency pressure oscillations (HFPO) during active voiding.
  • Rebound Phase:
    • Post-voiding, Pves increases as a rebound effect.
    • Indicates residual pressure changes after voiding.

Application of Laplace's Law

  • Formula:
    P=2TrP = \frac{2T}{r}P=r2T
    Where:
    • P = internal pressure
    • T = wall tension
    • r = radius
  • As the bladder fills, its radius increases, influencing pressure and tension.
  • Helps interpret pressure changes during filling and voiding, especially in detrusor overactivity or compliance issues.

Clinical Relevance

  • Key for diagnosing urological conditions:
    • Overactive bladder (OAB)
    • Bladder outlet obstruction
    • Neurogenic bladder dysfunction
  • Analyzing bladder pressure and compliance during each phase aids in personalized treatment strategies

Segment Ia is due to residual urine (Option A) - Residual urine is measured after voiding, not during the initial filling phase.

Micturition fails to happen in segment II (Option C) - Segment II is part of the filling phase; micturition hasn't been initiated yet, not failed.

Micturition occurs in segment Ib (Option D) - Segment Ib represents bladder filling with compliance; micturition occurs later, during the emptying phase.


Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7814486/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4092174/

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1 in the small intestine facilitates glucose absorption via sodium co-transport, critical for ORS effectiveness.


Na-Ca transporter (Option D): Involved in calcium homeostasis, not glucose absorption in the gut.

Reference:

  1. Sodium-Glucose Linked Transporters

questions.text: Calculate the sodium deficit in a 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg with a sodium level of 120 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Sodium Deficit Calculation:

  • Formula: Sodium Deficit (mEq) = (Desired Sodium - Current Sodium) x Total Body Water (TBW)

  • Total Body Water (TBW):
    • 60% of body weight (for males)
    • 50% of body weight (for females)
  • Therefore,
    • For a 70 kg male: TBW = 0.6 x 70 = 42 L
    • Desired sodium: 140 mEq/L (average range: 135-145 mEq/L)
    • Current sodium: 120 mEq/L
    • Sodium Deficit = (140 - 120) x 42 = 840 mEq

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied with Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, Cl: 4 mEq/L. Identify the compartment from which the fluid has been obtained.
questions.solution:
• The low sodium (Na+) concentration (10 mEq/L) is typical of intracellular fluid and contrasts with higher extracellular concentrations (135-145 mEq/L).
  • The high potassium (K+) concentration (140 mEq/L) is consistent with intracellular fluid levels.
  • The low chloride (Cl-) concentration (4 mEq/L) also aligns with intracellular fluid. Thus, the sample composition is characteristic of intracellular fluid.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3414807/

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in patients on warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Factor II (prothrombin) requires vitamin K-dependent gamma carboxylation, which is inhibited by warfarin, reducing its activity.


  • The carboxylation process adds gamma carboxyglutamate residues to these factors, allowing them to bind calcium ions and participate in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: Where is the location of the lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's hemianopic pupil occurs due to optic tract lesions, where pupillary fibers are affected before they branch off, causing a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) with homonymous hemianopia.


  • Pupillary reflexes are normal beyond the optic tract because pupillary fibres leave the optic tract before reaching LGB.
  • Wernicke's pupil is a type of RAPD where the abnormal pupillary response is associated with homonymous hemianopia.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
The enterogastric reflex is triggered by acid in the duodenum, which inhibits gastric emptying by reducing antral contractions and increasing pyloric sphincter tone.


Gastrocolic (Option A): The Gastrocolic reflex is a reflex that stimulates colonic motility and promotes the movement of feces from the colon to the rectum when food enters in the stomach leading to distension.

Intestino intestinal (Option B): When a part of the intestine is over-distended, the rest of the intestine relaxes. This is called intestine intestinal reflex.

Gastroilea (Option C): The Gastroileal reflex is a reflex that stimulates the emptying of the ileum, the final portion of the small intestine, by relaxing the ileocecal valve. It is not directly related to gastric emptying or the entry of acidic content into the duodenum.

questions.text: Which functional area is most likely to be impacted by the vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus in this female patient?

choices.text: There are no responses from the nociceptors when stimulated by blunt forceps
Pinching with toothed forceps cause stimulation of mechanonociceptors but no pain
Pricking with a needle does not stimulate nociceptors
Sharp pain sensation is carried by C fibres

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pinprick and toothed forceps with serrations is recorded as an output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What could be inferred from this?
questions.solution:
• Mechanical nociceptors respond to high-threshold mechanical stimuli, such as pinpricks and strong pressure, but not to non-noxious blunt stimuli.
  • Blunt forceps do not generate sufficient force to activate nociceptors, as they primarily stimulate low-threshold mechanoreceptors responsible for touch.

Pinching with toothed forceps causes stimulation of mechanonociceptors but no pain (Option B): Incorrect because nociceptors, when activated, do generate pain.

Pricking with a needle does not stimulate nociceptors (Option C): Incorrect because pricking is a strong mechanical stimulus that activates nociceptors.

Sharp pain sensation is carried by C fibers (Option D): Incorrect because sharp pain is carried by Aδ fibers, while C fibers transmit slow, burning pain.

questions.text:
Choose the correct options from the given statements of the enteric nervous system?
1.Vagus is the only afferent from gut
2. Functions independent of brain and SC
3. Myenteric plexus in the lamina propria
4. Exclusively under the influence of nerves
5. Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS
questions.solution:
• The enteric nervous system (ENS) is a self-regulating system that can function independently of the brain and spinal cord (SC), controlling gut motility, secretion, and blood flow.
  • Vagus is not the only afferent from the gut; the gut also has spinal afferents that carry pain and reflex information.
  • The myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers, not in the lamina propria.

Auerbach plexus between two sets of muscles

  • The ENS is influenced by hormones and local factors, not exclusively by nerves.
  • The parasympathetic nervous system (via vagus and pelvic nerves) connects the ENS to the CNS, modulating its activity.

1,2,3 (Option A): Incorrect because the vagus is not the only afferent, and the myenteric plexus is not in the lamina propria.

1,4 (Option B): Incorrect because ENS is not exclusively under neural influence; hormones and local factors also regulate it.

1,3 (Option C): Incorrect because both vagus-only afferent and myenteric plexus location statements are wrong.

questions.text:
LMN lesions are associated with?
1. Decrease in muscle tone
2. Spastic paralysis
3. Babinski positive
4. Fasciculations
questions.solution:
• Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesions affect the anterior horn cells or peripheral nerves, leading to flaccid paralysis with loss of reflexes and muscle atrophy.
  • Decrease in muscle tone occurs due to loss of motor input to muscles, leading to flaccidity.
  • Fasciculations are spontaneous twitches of motor units due to denervation hypersensitivity.
  • Spastic paralysis and Babinski sign are features of Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions, not LMN lesions.

1,2 (Option A): Incorrect because spastic paralysis occurs in UMN lesions, not LMN.

1,2,3 (Option B): Incorrect because Babinski sign is a feature of UMN lesions.

1,2,3,4 (Option C): Incorrect because spastic paralysis and Babinski sign are not seen in LMN lesions.

questions.text: Not seen in decompression sickness?
questions.solution:
• Decompression sickness (DCS) is caused by nitrogen bubble formation due to rapid ascent from high-pressure environments.
  • Vision loss can occur due to air embolism affecting the retinal circulation.
  • Hearing loss can result from inner ear barotrauma or vestibulocochlear involvement.
  • Coagulopathy occurs due to vascular injury and activation of coagulation pathways.
  • Hemodilution is not seen in DCS because the condition primarily leads to dehydration, not plasma volume expansion.

Pathophysiology of Decompression Sickness


Vision loss (Option A): Incorrect because air embolism can cause retinal artery occlusion.

Hearing loss (Option B): Incorrect because inner ear barotrauma and nitrogen bubbles can affect hearing.

Coagulopathy (Option D): Incorrect because bubble-induced endothelial damage triggers clotting abnormalities.

choices.text: A- Z line B- A band C-I band D-H band
A-Z line B- I band C- A band D- H band
A-M line B-I band C-H band D-I band
A-M line B-I band C- A band D- H band

questions.text: Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?
questions.solution:
• A (Z line): Dark vertical line marking the boundary between sarcomeres and anchoring actin filaments.
  • B (I band): Light region containing only thin actin filaments; shortens during contraction.
  • C (A band): Dark region containing thick myosin filaments, with actin overlapping; remains unchanged in length.
  • D (H band): Lighter central part of A band with only myosin filaments; disappears during contraction.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to?
questions.solution:
• Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) primarily respond to low arterial oxygen (PaO₂).
  • They are activated when PaO₂ falls below 60 mmHg, increasing ventilation to restore oxygen levels.
  • While they also respond to hypercapnia and acidosis, the central chemoreceptors in the medulla are more sensitive to CO₂ and pH changes.


Hypercapnia (Option A): Incorrect because central chemoreceptors primarily regulate CO₂ levels, while peripheral chemoreceptors have a weaker response.

Acidosis (Option C): Incorrect because although peripheral chemoreceptors detect acidosis, central chemoreceptors play a dominant role.

Alkalosis (Option D): Incorrect because alkalosis does not significantly stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors

Reference: Chemoreceptor relfex

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR?
questions.solution:
• Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) depends on filtration surface area and membrane permeability, both represented by the glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf).
  • A decrease in Kf occurs due to glomerular damage, thickening of the basement membrane, or mesangial cell contraction, leading to reduced filtration.
  • Conditions like chronic kidney disease (CKD) and diabetic nephropathy reduce Kf, thereby decreasing GFR.

Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure (Option B): Incorrect because lower oncotic pressure would increase filtration, thereby increasing GFR.

Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure (Option C): Incorrect because higher hydrostatic pressure in the glomerulus promotes filtration, increasing GFR.

Decrease of Bowman's hydrostatic pressure (Option D): Incorrect because a lower Bowman's capsule pressure would reduce resistance to filtration, leading to an increase in GFR.

questions.text: Blood pressure changes in the radial artery were measured while performing a valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
In Phase I of the Valsalva maneuver, increased intrathoracic pressure is transmitted to the aorta, causing a transient rise in aortic (and arterial) pressure.



Incorrect Options:

A) Increase in left ventricular volume - LV volume decreases due to reduced venous return from increased intrathoracic pressure.

B) Decrease in left ventricular pressure - LV pressure initially increases, not decreases, due to external compression from raised thoracic pressure.

D) Decrease in aortic pressure - Aortic pressure transiently rises in Phase I, not falls; a drop occurs later in Phase II.

Reference: Valsalva Maneuver - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: If the pH is reduced from 7.4 to 7.3 with the PO2 being constant at 100 mmHg, which line would PaCO2 follow?
questions.solution:
Line 1 shows the steepest increase in ventilation for a given PaCO2, reflecting the strong respiratory compensation at pH 7.3.

The reduction in pH from 7.4 to 7.3 would trigger a compensatory response by the respiratory system to increase the excretion of carbon dioxide, which would lead to a decrease in PaCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood). This response is known as respiratory compensation.

Relationship Between Minute Ventilation (MV) and Arterial Carbon Dioxide Tension (PaCO2)

Key Highlights

  • Graphical Trend:
    • MV increases inversely with PaCO2 to maintain acid-base balance.
    • High PaCO2 lowers blood pH (acidosis), triggering increased ventilation to expel CO2 and restore pH.

Effects of pH on MV and PaCO2

  • Physiological Regulation:
    • CO2 combines with water to form carbonic acid, dissociating into bicarbonate and hydrogen ions, lowering pH.
    • Chemoreceptors detect pH changes and adjust MV to normalize CO2 levels.

Incorrect options:

Option B) Line 2 - Represents a milder response than needed for pH 7.3, suggesting less sensitivity to CO2.

Option C) Line 3 - Matches the normal ventilatory response at pH 7.4, not the increased drive seen in acidosis.

Option D) Line 4 - Indicates a blunted response, typical of alkalosis or depressed respiratory drive, not acidosis.

Reference: Effect of stepwise reduction in minute ventilation on PaCO2 in ventilated newborns - PubMed

questions.text:
The correct sequence of events during vomiting are?

1. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
2. Strong contractions in the stomach
3. Inspiration against a closed glottis
4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter
5. Relaxation of upper esophageal sphincter
6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine
questions.solution:
Sequence of Events During Vomiting

  1. Reverse Peristalsis in the Small Intestine:
    • Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach, possibly introducing bile into the vomit.
  2. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter:
    • In severe cases, the pyloric sphincter relaxes, facilitating the expulsion of gastric and duodenal contents.
  3. Inspiration Against a Closed Glottis:
    • A deep breath is taken while the glottis remains closed, creating negative pressure in the thoracic cavity.
  4. Strong Contractions in the Stomach:
    • Abdominal muscles and diaphragm contract, increasing intragastric pressure, propelling contents upward.
  5. Relaxation of Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES):
    • LES relaxes, allowing stomach contents to move into the esophagus.
  6. Relaxation of Upper Esophageal Sphincter (UES):
    • UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit through the mouth.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4230971/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8198651/

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Insensible water loss is the amount of water lost from the body through evaporation, such as through the skin or respiratory tract that cannot be easily measured. Normal insensible water loss is generally considered to be around 30-50 mL/hour in adults.

Insensible Water Loss

  • Definition:
    • Unconscious water loss through skin diffusion and respiration, distinct from sensible losses (urine and feces).
  • Typical Values:
    • Total loss: 600 to 800 mL/day. (~35ml-50ml/hour)
    • Skin diffusion: 300 to 400 mL/day.
    • Respiratory loss: 250 to 350 mL/day.
    • Represents 30% to 50% of total daily water loss.
  • Factors Influencing Loss:
    • Environmental conditions: Higher temperatures and lower humidity increase evaporative loss.
    • Physical activity: Increases respiratory rate, enhancing water loss.
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Key in managing fluid balance in patients, especially during surgery or in conditions affecting hydration.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3105115/

choices.text: Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?
questions.solution:
• In Type II membrane proteins, the signal-anchor sequence is a hydrophobic transmembrane domain that integrates into the lipid bilayer.
  • This non-cleavable sequence directs the protein to the membrane, anchoring it in place, with the N-terminal in the cytoplasm and the C-terminal facing the extracellular space or lumen.

Type II Membrane Proteins Overview

  • Signal-Anchor Sequence:
    • Contains a non-cleavable signal-anchor sequence that anchors the protein to the membrane, unlike type I proteins.
    • Functions as both a signal and membrane anchor during protein synthesis.
  • Orientation:
    • N-terminal is directed towards the cytoplasm.
    • C-terminal faces the extracellular space or the lumen of organelles (e.g., ER, Golgi).
  • Insertion Mechanism:
    • Insertion occurs cotranslationally into the ER.
    • The signal-anchor sequence directs the polypeptide to the translocon.
    • Positively charged amino acids before the transmembrane domain ensure proper orientation.
  • Examples:
    • Transferrin receptor and glycosyltransferases.

At the C-terminal (Option B): : The signal-anchor sequence is not at the C-terminal; it is near the N-terminal, which faces the cytoplasm.

At the N-terminal (Option C): The N-terminal faces the cytoplasm but does not contain the signal-anchor sequence, which is located near it.

Both inside the membrane and at the C-terminal (Option D): The signal-anchor sequence is inside the membrane but not at the C-terminal; it functions as a transmembrane domain.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4214783/

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory?
questions.solution:
• Short-term memory (STM), also called working memory, is the brain's temporary storage system used for immediate tasks such as reasoning or learning.
  • It retains information for a brief period, typically lasting 30 to 300 seconds (0.5 to 5 minutes).
  • Beyond this timeframe, information either decays or transfers to long-term memory if rehearsed or encoded.

Short-term memory:

  • Short-term memory retains information for durations ranging from seconds to several hours.
  • The ventral hippocampus, specifically the CA1 region, is responsible for short-term memory.
  • Through rehearsal or repetition, short-term memories can be consolidated into long-term memories.

Long-term memory:

  • Long-term memory retains information for years or even a lifetime.
  • The neocortex serves as the centre for long-term memory storage.

3-6 hours (Option A): This duration is associated with long-term memory consolidation, not short-term memory. Short-term memory is transient and does not last for hours without active rehearsal.

12-18 hours (Option B): This duration pertains to retained information in long-term memory or residual effects of memory retention after learning. Short-term memory operates on a much shorter timescale.

3-4 seconds (Option D): This duration corresponds to sensory memory, particularly echoic (auditory) or iconic (visual) memory, which lasts only a few seconds before decaying. It is not the same as short-term memory.

questions.text: During exercise, once a state of balance is achieved, it was observed that the body's oxygen consumption rate was 1500 ml/min. To determine the MET score, consider a baseline oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a unit used to estimate energy expenditure during physical activity, defined as the ratio of metabolic rate during activity to resting metabolic rate.

Formula to Calculate MET:

MET=Oxygen consumption during exercise/ Resting oxygen consumption

Given:

  • Oxygen consumption during exercise = 1500 ml/min
  • Resting oxygen consumption = 250 ml/min

Calculation:

MET=1500ml/min/250ml/min=6

Thus, the MET score is 6, indicating that the energy expenditure during exercise is 6 times higher than at rest.

Factors affecting MET:

Body weight: Heavier individuals generally have a higher absolute energy expenditure during physical activities than lighter individuals.

Fitness level: More physically fit tend to have a more efficient cardiovascular system and improved oxygen utilization, resulting in lower energy expenditure for the same activity than individuals with lower fitness levels.

Age: Generally, younger individuals have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities than older individuals.

Activity duration and intensity: Longer durations or higher intensity activities result in higher energy expenditure.

Body composition: Individuals with a higher percentage of lean muscle mass typically have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities.

Environmental factors: Extreme temperatures or high altitudes can increase the body's energy demands, leading to higher energy expenditure and potentially higher MET values.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2204507/

questions.text:
Which of the subsequent factors experiences an elevation in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
1. FRC
2. TLC
3. VC
4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution: In COPD, FRC and TLC are increased due to air trapping and lung hyperinflation. Vital Capacity (VC) decreases, and the FEV₁/FVC ratio is reduced, typical of obstructive lung diseases.
